Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Extreme band engineering in polarization graded nanowire heterostructures for high efficiency photonics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This project will advance the academic and public understanding of the principles of optical/electronic materials used for photonics through laboratory research and educational outreach. Wide bandgap III-Nitride semiconductors span the ultraviolet-visible-near infrared spectrum finding energy efficient applications in ultraviolet-visible light sources and detectors. Self-assembled Nitride nanowires increase the design flexibility in heterostructures due to high tolerance to lattice mismatch. This project will achieve new types of optical and electrical functionality in nanowire heterostructures for advanced high efficiency photonics. In bulk, polarization charge and bandgaps in GaN, AlN, and InN cannot be maintained in a single heterostructure without generating large numbers of dislocations due to strain relaxation. Nanowires sidestep the constraint of epitaxial strain making possible extreme energy landscapes for electrons and holes in graded AlGaN and InGaN heterostructures, while maintaining single crystal defect-free active regions. A remarkable array of heterostructures are possible exhibiting large built-in electric fields due to polarization charge that separate electrons and holes with high speed and efficiency, properties that enable high speed photodetectors covering a broad range in energy. Polarization grading will also be used to achieve impurity free p and n type doping in nanowires, which sidesteps the problem of impurity doping in nanostructures, and will be used to demonstrate a dopant-free pn-junction LED. To achieve these heterostructures, a systematic mapping of the growth phase diagram of molecular beam epitaxy growth of self-assembled GaN and InN nanowires on Si (111) for arbitrary selection of nanowire diameter and density will be investigated, and a suite of structural, optical, and electronic techniques will be employed, including SEM, Z-contrast TEM, XRD, time-resolved photoluminescence, electroluminescence, nanowire transport, and trap spectroscopy to examine fundamental transport and optical properties as they relate to nanowire structure and polarization charge/doping phenomena.
NonTechnical: Controlling how atoms combine to form nanoscale crystals of semiconductors allows efficient conversion of light to electricity, and vice versa. However, even scientifically inclined students and teachers are largely unaware of the foundations of remarkable solar conversion, lighting, and display technologies, and completely unaware of the science of crystal growth. To address this shortfall, tutorials and lab demonstrations geared toward high school students will be integrated into the extensive outreach infrastructure at Ohio State, including open houses and summer camps that target minority students and women. A series of day long and summer camp events in the department of Materials Science and Engineering will take part in a hands-on tutorial/lab demonstration on materials for electro-optical energy conversion. The same tutorial will be remotely beamed to high school students around the country through the Electronics Experts program at the COSI science museum, which also provides a framework for tutorial development, and evaluation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of this project was to take advantage of the unique engineering capabilities present in nanomaterials in order to develop high efficiency optical and electronic functionality. The first goal was to systematically develop synthesis methods of nanowires formed from AlGaN and InGaN, which are compound semiconductors with optical capabilities spanning the ultraviolet, visible, and infrared wavelengths. We developed nanowires capable of covering the entire composition range of these alloys. In the course of the project we utilized the specially developed synthesis methods to demonstrate several new effects. We developed the first dopantless diodes, which are light emitting diodes formed without using impurity-doping, but rather using polarization-induced doping. These structures were used to demonstrate the first deep ultraviolet light emitting diodes formed from nanowires. Besides, this proof of concept work, we performed detailed scientific studies including the first systematic exploration of polarization-induced hole doping. Besides the polarization-induced LED work, we used our precise synthesis methods to demonstrate the first coaxial quantum electronic devices in nanowires, called coaxial nanowire resonant tunneling diodes. In addition to the polarization-doping effect, graded composition nanowires were used to demonstrate a new optoelectronic effect, called "negative differential photocurrent", equivalent to a photosensor that changes the sign of its ouput as the light intensity increases. Overall this funded NSF grant resulted in 18 peer-reviewed publications, 4 PhD dissertations, and 2 patents. In terms of work force development, this project involved the research training of 11 diverse undergraduate students, and 4 graduate students that now all have industry positions. In terms of public outreach, the grant supported lab tours, demonstrations, and workshops for teachers and high school students. In terms of advancement of education, the PI developed a new graduate course, "epitaxial heterostructures", that trains graduate students the advance synthesis methods to engineer nanomaterials for optoelectronic functionality. Additionaly, the PI developed a new undergraduate course, "Materials for Energy Technology", which trains undergraduates in the state-of-the-art technology and existing materials issues within the energy conversion industries. Both courses have been taught consistently (since 2014 and 2012, respectively) and are permaneant parts of the MSE department's curriculum.
